column4: Why does uname -a show me an older version of a kernel. I have it listing 2.6.31-20-generic when i have 2.6.32-21-generic in /boot
are you actually running the -21 kernel?
what? $ uname -a
i imagine you've still got both versions in /boot, and are running the old one at the moment.
yes, the older one is listed in /boot, i want to upgrade to the newer one :)
does it not appear in the grub menu at boot?
the new kernel should come up by default. remote kernel upgrades are always dicey: have you got someone on the other end to kick the machine if the new kernel has problems?
or have ipmi working, &cet.
i did sudo reboot now after sudo apt-get upgrade
check the config file and make sure it says what you think it does...
/boot/grub/grub.cfg
# DO NOT EDIT THIS FILE
i said "make sure it says what you think it does"
and it does not, the menuentry is for 2.6.31-20 only
well, there you go
i would verify that the kernel package was installed properly
should've been done by the package, i should think...anyway, glad it's working.
you might try reinstalling the kernel package first. where there no errors? also, you'll want a copy of grub.cfg...
just reinstall the kernel packages you updated.
what part of "beta"...
it ain't released yet. that's why it's called "release candidate" , and not "release".
